natural problem: What is the degree measure of an interior angle of a regular pentagon?
natural solution: Any convex pentagon may be subdivided into three triangles, each with a total angle sum of 180 degrees.

Thus, the sum of the interior angles of any convex pentagon is $3 \times 180 = 540$ degrees. If the pentagon is regular, then each of its five angles will have the same measure of $540 \div 5 = \boxed{108\text{ degrees}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: real
assumes h0 : "n = 5"
shows  "(180 * (n - 2)) / n = 108"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the degree measure of an interior angle of a regular pentagon? The final Answer is 108\text{ degrees}
 ### Proof
 Any convex pentagon may be subdivided into three triangles, each with a total angle sum of 180 degrees.
 Thus, the sum of the interior angles of any convex pentagon is $3 \times 180 = 540$ degrees. If the pentagon is regular, then each of its five angles will have the same measure of $540 \div 5 = \boxed{108\text{ degrees}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: real
assumes h0 : "n = 5"
shows  "(180 * (n - 2)) / n = 108"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: "If a regular polygon has 5 sides, what is the measure of each interior angle? The final answer is 108 degrees."

 ### Proof

 *)

theorem
fixes angle :: real
assumes h0 : "5 * (angle - 2) * 180 = 360"
shows  "angle = 108"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the value of the angle if 5 times the difference between the angle and 2, when multiplied by 180, equals 360. The final answer is 108.
